importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lindsay Sandiford was arrested at Bali’s airport in 2012 after carrying 3.8 kg of cocaine, leading to her imprisonment and eventual sentencing to death by firing squad.
Indonesia’s highest court upheld Lindsay Sandiford’s death sentence in 2013, marking a key moment in the timeline of her legal case.
Shahab Shahabadi was arrested in Jakarta in 2014 and sentenced to life imprisonment for methamphetamine trafficking.
Indonesia carried out its last executions in July 2016, including a citizen and three foreigners, indicating a potential shift in execution policy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from 2012 to 2025 covers the period during which Lindsay Sandiford was imprisoned and the eventual repatriation deal was finalized, highlighting the long-term international legal and human rights implications.

keyTakeAways: Lindsay Sandiford, a 68-year-old British woman, was sentenced to death by firing squad in Indonesia in 2013 after being arrested in 2012 with 3.8 kg of cocaine hidden in her suitcase.
She claimed she was forced to carry the drugs by a drug gang threatening her children, adding a human rights and moral dimension to her case.
The Indonesian government, under President Prabowo Subianto, has repatriated several foreign nationals under bilateral agreements, including the repatriation of Sandiford and Shahab Shahabadi.
Shahab Shahabadi, a 35-year-old man from Iran, was sentenced to life imprisonment in 2014 for methamphetamine trafficking and remains in prison.
The repatriation deal was signed by British Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and Indonesia’s Senior Minister of Law Yusril Ihza Mahendra.
Indonesia has a high number of foreign prisoners on death row—about 100 foreigners out of 530 death row inmates—many due to drug-related offenses, despite strict drug laws.
The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime identifies Indonesia as a major drug smuggling hub due to its role in trafficking networks targeting young populations.
Indonesia has not carried out executions since 2016, suggesting a shift in its execution policy, possibly influenced by international human rights pressure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, 68, was sentenced to death by firing squad in Indonesia in 2013 after being arrested in 2012 with 3.8 kg of cocaine hidden in her suitcase, claiming she was coerced by a drug gang threatening her children. The case drew international attention due to her advanced age and health, and she was spared execution through a repatriation agreement signed between the UK and Indonesia in October 2025. Another foreign national, Shahab Shahabadi, a 35-year-old Iranian man serving a life sentence for methamphetamine trafficking, was also included in the deal. The agreement was facilitated by UK Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and Indonesia’s Senior Minister of Law Yusril Ihza Mahendra. Indonesia, under President Prabowo Subianto, has repatriated several foreign prisoners under bilateral agreements, reflecting both a human rights response and a broader diplomatic trend. The country holds around 100 foreign prisoners on death row, many for drug-related crimes, despite being a major drug smuggling hub. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime highlights Indonesia’s role in drug trafficking, emphasizing global concerns about strict drug laws and human rights violations.
title: British Grandmother Spared Firing Squad in Repatriation Deal with Indonesia
